bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to F.M. Boldridge, May 4, 1922

div1.p: Carter gives Boldridge advice regarding Guatemala, including precautions to take. He offers his opinions about the people of Latin America.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to F.M. Boldridge, May 4, 1922
div1.opener:
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
May 4, 1922.
Dr. F. M. Boldridge, Health Officer,
City of Chester, S. C.
Dear Doctor Boldridge:
div1.p:
Except that you have so informed me, I would not have known that
the Sarstoon River Valley was in Guatemala. It doubtless is, however!
I think I can tell you that there is no yellow fever in Guatemala at
present.

If your friends are in the lower part of the Valley, anywhere near
sea level, there should be a reasonable or unreasonable amount of mal-
aria. If they are in the uplands, not so much.

Whether or not they can make a success of the project you speak of
depends primarily upon three factors: 1/ Transportation, whether they
can make it good and reasonably cheap: 2/ Health Conditions, whether
they can keep their working force and themselves in decent health--es-
pecially as regards malaria and dysentary: 3/ How they can handle their
labor situation. I know nothing about the first. For the 2nd., dysen-
tary is easily enough prevented by boiling your water supply: eschew-
ing uncooked vegatebles. Malaria is a more difficult problem: They
had best arrange for someone pretty well used to Anopheles control
and he had better use quinine freely until he can get his Anopheles con-
trolled. They should shun liquor as the Devil is said to do holy water;
the American cannot drink and succeed in the tropics.

In handling labor they should not expect a peon at from 25 cents
to to 50 cents a day to do as much an American at $2.50. If they do, they
will be disappointed, and any attempt to force or bully Latin American
or Indian workmen leads inevitably to disaster. They appreate decent
treatment, but also the boss must be the boss.

I notice you speak of coming down "this summer or fall when these
cases are called. I judge they won't come up any time shortly then? My
health was all right when you last saw me--not so good now.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
